Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI will continue his study of analysis and geometry as it relates to complex numbers. Complex numbers and functions of complex variables have become very useful tools in the study of other areas of pure mathematics and in the application of mathematics. For instance, the study of airflow over a wing uses complex numbers and complex functions to model this flow. The subject continues to be a vital and important topic in the mathematical sciences. Realizing this, the PI has recently begun teaching what is called Advanced Engineering Mathematics. Teaching this material shows in a precise sense how the proposed research develops higher dimensional analogues of fundamental mathematics currently used throughout physics and engineering. In addition to the mathematical research, the PI will also work with the Engineering College at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign on fine-tuning the curriculum in Advanced Engineering Mathematics.


Hermitian analysis has its roots in 19th century mathematics. The subject began, two centuries ago, with the work of Fourier on heat diffusion.It has developed using the theory of Hilbert spaces, by its applications to quantum mechanics, and via its role in signal processing. Modern Hermitian analysis both relies upon and informs complex analysis and CR geometry, the PI's primary research areas. The modern point of view emphasizes the tools of orthonormal expansion and orthogonal projection. The PI has introduced an algebraic technique called orthogonal homogenization which connects these ideas to the geometry of proper mappings between balls. The PI has reformulated one of his older results, on volumes of proper images of balls, as a variational problem, thereby extending the results to considerably more general situations. The PI's work on proper mappings between balls in different dimensional complex spaces has also uncovered unexpected connections to representation theory and algebraic combinatorics. The primary purposes of this research are to extend the ideas of orthogonal homogenization to the rational case, to establish additional variational inequalities, to study homotopy for proper holomorphic mappings of positive codimension, and to further develop the subject of CR complexity. In the process the PI will continue to mentor young mathematicians in these topics and to organize and attend conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Grant DMS 13-61001 supported the PI to continue his study of Hermitian Analysisand CR Geometry. One major achievement supported by this grant was the completion and publication of the second edition of the book ``Hermitian Analysis: From Fourier Series to Cauchy-Riemann Geometry''. The PI added a new chapter based on his joint work with a postdoctoral fellow here at Illinois from 2015 to 2017. This joint work, appearing in three published papers, introduced five symmetry groups associated with proper mappings between balls, a fundamental topic in the function theory of several complex variables. These groups help unify the results of many authors over the past three decades and open up new lines of investigation as well. In addition, separate work with a former postdoc introduced considerations of homotopy into the study of CR mappings between spheres, thereby making connections with geometry and topology. The grant also supported two PhD students in their work. In addition, the PI published another book supported by this grant; ``Linear and Complex Analysis for Applications'' has been used as a textbook for a course in Advanced Engineering Mathematics. The mathematics therein has been influenced by the research of the PI, and thus speaks to the broader impacts of the grant.The PI has spoken on these topics at meetings in Brazil, Italy, Slovenia, Czech Republic, and Austria as well as at many places in the US. These invitations indicate the level of international interest in the research and speaking at these meetings provides additional dissemination of the results.


Cauchy-Riemann (CR) Geometry studies the geometry of real objects in complex spaces and the mappings between them.The most important example is the unit sphere; CR mappings between spheres generalize some of the most importantideas in classical one-dimensional complex analysis, such as Fourier series, harmonic analysis, and conformal mapping. Hermitian analysis is a term introduced by the PI to describe the use of Hermitian forms in CR Geometry.The symmetry of the unit sphere in complex Euclidean space allows for many CR mappings. When one allows the source and target dimensions to differ, one obtains even more examples. As the target dimension rises, the moduli space of examples has itself arbitrarily large dimension. A complete classification is perhaps impossible.The PI has studied the consequences of these results for several decades, including the connections to other branches of mathematics such as combinatorial number theory, invariant theory,  and Hermitian analysis.The grant enabled this work to evolve to a higher level, introduced several young mathematicians into the area, and aided in the publication of two books and many research papers.
